abstract.p: Ceremony will be held to mark completion of exterior of 11-story cooperative apartment building in Harlem that is intended to test area's appeal to middle-income buyers (S)

block.p: A ceremony will be held today to mark the completion of the exterior of an 11-story cooperative apartment building in Harlem that is intended to test the area's appeal to middle-income buyers.

More than 4,000 applications were received for the 240 apartments at the building, the Renaissance, on 116th Street and Lenox Avenue, the developers said. To qualify, an applicant needs a before-tax income of $25,488 to $140,500, depending on the size of the family and the apartment.
A ceremony will be held today to mark the completion of the exterior of an 11-story cooperative apartment building in Harlem that is intended to test the area's appeal to middle-income buyers.

More than 4,000 applications were received for the 240 apartments at the building, the Renaissance, on 116th Street and Lenox Avenue, the developers said. To qualify, an applicant needs a before-tax income of $25,488 to $140,500, depending on the size of the family and the apartment.

The apartments cost from $4,056 to $14,637, with monthly maintenance from $709 to $2,558. The residents will be chosen by lottery within about a month, said one of the developers, Jeffrey E. Levine, the president of Levine Builders of Queens.
The project, built largely with public money, is part of a city effort to encourage retail development in poor areas. The tenants include Rite Aid, Met Foods and Petland.
